Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:51AM GG27 wrote: chickenpants, I just noticed you are in Nanaimo, I'm just across the strait from you & had all my surgeries & most of my treatment in Nanaimo & found them to be fantastic there.  I had to go down to Victoria for onco visits & rads, but I was very pleased with our medical system. The waiting was the worst part.  My onco says that most of the cancers start years before & so having to wait a few weeks is not going to let the disease progress.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2010 06:04PM GG27 wrote: I didn't realize that Nuerontin was Gabapentin.  I do have some insight on it, I took it for about 4 months after chemo because the neuropathy was so painful.  I had no side effects from it, other than being a bit sleepy.  I've actually just gone back on it, it's shown to ease hot flashes (I have about 15 per day) & help with sleep which last night I slept for 3 hours straight which I hadn't done for 6 months.  There was a really good double blind study done on it. HTH, Dee
Posts.Title: Neuropathy Char2010 ktym

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2010 11:42AM GG27 wrote: I don't have any experience with Nuerontin, but I had neuropathy really badly in my toes & tried acupuncture which took it away completely, but I notice it's back a little bit, so I probably need to go again. It lasted for about 8-9 months & it's certainly not as bad as it was, it's quite livable, but I suspect it will get worse over time again. Good luck, Dee
Posts.Title: Neuropathy Char2010 ktym

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2017 10:54PM GG27 wrote: I think that Prolia is the newer maybe a bit better drug than pamidronate. But yes, it's for bone strengthening & helps with recurrence. And it doesn't cost us $1200! They will do labs, calcium & creatinine to make sure your kidneys are ok.
Posts.Title: prolia Faithhope35 GG27

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 02:35PM GG27 wrote: I didn't see your question til now, but I had the same issue & talked to all the Dr's like you did.  I tried doing weight training to try to get rid of it.  This didn't work until I got tendonitis in my shoulder.  At that point the Dr gave me anti inflammitories & a corisone shot, within a few days my arms feel back to normal again after 6 months of non stop pain. Hopefully this will work for you as good as it did for me. Cheers, Dee

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2016 11:27AM GG27 wrote: Ok, I see now what you're saying.... my understanding is that I can try several different AI's and still be first line, stage iv? But as BB says, each different type of therapy is a another line? Perhaps this is why new MO says we could go back to tamoxifen when I recurred on it. So it would seem that would be why you are having trouble getting Ibrance covered because you started Femera? But that doesn't make sense because you can take Femera with Ibrance.... oh man, I just don't know, sorry. DD, you do have to be an advocate for yourself I'm afraid. As both Linda & I and many others have discovered, there seems to be too many of us here & our Dr's are overwhelmed. I have brought a number of things up to my Dr's.
Posts.Title: Confused first line second line third etc. dancingdiva LindaE54

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2016 10:13AM GG27 wrote: I'm just going to jump in here too. Linda & DD, I was on tamoxifen for 6 years, anastrozole for 2+, I'm still considered first line until Tuesday (fingers crossed) when I will start the Palestra Trial, taking Ibrance/Letrozole. My new MO says also that if I have too many SE's on Letrozole, I took it before & it was horrible, then I can go back to Tamoxifen or Anastrozole or try one of the others on the list or none at all. This is why I asked about it being part of the trial as Deanna suggested & MO said no, this trial was only looking at the efficacy of Ibrance at different dosages over a 28 day period. But I have noticed that different MO's have very different ideas about these things, so while our situations may seem similar you may have very different conversations with your insurance companies & MO's. If you are having problems getting Ibrance covered can you talk to your MO about getting in the Palestra trial?

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 11:13AM GG27 wrote: When I had my BMX, Jan 08, I said I wasn't have reconstruction, couldn't imagine going through all that surgery again, my breasts didn't define who I was.  I struggled with the decision even the day before surgery, I wasn't happy with my flat chest, my clothes didn't hang right, I felt self concious, so I changed my mind.  I had a bi-lat lat dorsi flap with TE's in February & couldn't be happier.  I wish I could be like all the ladies here whom I admire for being so comfortable in their skin, but apparently I'm not. :) This is not to say you should or shouldn't, I just thought you might benefit from my experience.  Good luck in your decision, Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 11:21PM GG27 wrote: Barbe, the woman really was trying to be helpful.  She had a BMX many years ago & I guess no woman then would have considered going out in a t-shirt like I had on, without the benefit of prothesis.  My dad just kind of shook his head...  I know what you mean about the fabric against your chest, it feels so good, my PS has assured me that I will never have to wear a bra. Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 02:40PM GG27 wrote: Suzybelle, I'm glad you don't care what people think, for me, no one ever made me feel bad, it was all me.  Although when I went to visit my parents, one woman went up to my dad & asked if I'd had a BMX, because I would look much better if I wore prothesis.  I wasn't wearing them because I had bad burns from radiation & couldn't stand to wear a bra.  She was trying to be helpful! :) Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 11:24AM GG27 wrote: All of you are right of course, she did speak without thinking of how it might come across, but the part that kind of astounded me, was asking my dad about it instead of coming to me.  But then I'm constantly amazed at the rude or intrusive things that people say to total strangers.  It will be interesting to see what she has to say when we go back up there in May. Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2014 10:17AM GG27 wrote: None of you are alone in this. I too can't stand the over hype of Christmas & all of the "must haves" for the holidays. If you don't have this thing & that thing.... or buy expensive gifts then you just aren't in the spirit of the season. I think it's a tough time of year for lots of folks, but once you don't have your health anymore, even though most of us are doing quite well, you realize that none of that BS matters anymore. DH & I have certainly discovered that, we don't care about "things" anymore. We spend our money out enjoying life & find that these serious conversations about the most trivial things make my eyes roll inadvertently. A friend said to me a few months ago "oh I just can't stand it anymore, I just want to give up" What was she talking about? a few weeds in her immaculate garden. This was supposed to be her pep talk to me when I was going through a really rough patch just finding out I was stage IV & thought I was dying immediately. I guess she thought we were relating to each others situation. So virtual hugs to you MrsM & everyone else! Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: I've Got the Blahs DivineMrsM Kjones13

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 11:24PM GG27 wrote: I had this happen to me when I had my lat flap/TE's, luckily just before I went under I was able to yell at him & ask the nurse to please do something.  The pain & burning was intense & I could feel the blood dripping down my arm.  I complained to my PS afterwards, because as you know, we don't usually know who our anesthestist is.  I told PS that I never want that Dr again.  Your surgeon will have the name.  I'm sorry that you too had this experience, I had hoped when it happened to me it was just an anomoly.
Posts.Title: General Anesthetic: horrible pain in arm when being put under gumshoe christina0001

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 06:55PM GG27 wrote: I was very certain that I would not be having reconstruction so I instructed my BS to take as much as he could & leave my chest very smooth with no extra skin.  I ended up having recon, but the PS said it didn't matter that I had no extra skin, he was able to make beautiful breasts for me.  My point is, if you don't want to do it now but are worried that you won't be able to change your mind & have it later due to them taking too much skin, don't be, do what you feel is best for you right now.  My PS was telling me he just did recon on a 70 yo woman who had a BMX 20 years ago, she decided she really wanted to have it done, so it's never too late to change your mind if you want to.   Good luck!

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2014 01:41PM GG27 wrote: I got headaches from anastrozole for about the first 2 weeks or so, I took tylenol, now it's not a problem.  But I have a serious reaction to morphine, it causes severe dehydration which causes severe headaches.  So it could be a combination of the 2?  Can you take something other than morphine?  When I have a situation that calls for morphine they give me demeral.  GG
Posts.Title: Taking Anastrozole Having Headaches..!!! Bonitaj Bonitaj

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2014 09:53AM GG27 wrote: So it sounds like the morphine isn't the problem, the anastrozole is.   If you keep getting the headaches, perhaps ask your onco to either change you to another AI or try another brand.  I had issues with some of the brands, anything with lactose as a filler was a problem for me.  Now anastrozole has a small amount of lactose, but I seem to be able to tolerate it as long as I don't eat anything else with a lot of lactose.  HTH, GG

Posts.Title: How long have you been Stage IV? goldie0827 dormouse

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2015 02:18AM GG27 wrote: Deanna, I was pretty much a vegetarian before I was diagnosed the first time. About 1 year before stage IV, I had to start eating more protein as I was so anemic. So I started eating quite a bit more meat. My onc doesn't feel that has any bearing on my stage IV diagnosis, she attributes that to the 40+ tumors that were found when I had a BMX. When I started eating more protein, my energy levels went up, my joint pain disappeared and I lost 35 lbs. GG
Posts.Title: Plant based, vegetarian or vegan diets for Stage IV dlb823 mkinoly

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2015 12:57PM GG27 wrote: ThedivineMrsM, thank you so much for posting that article. I have sent it off to my friend who has stage IV colon cancer & she too hates the language of cancer & how she has somehow failed not the treatment failed. I'm afraid I didn't know much about MBC until I was diagnosed with it, so I don't expect others to "get it" But I do get annoyed with friends who say to me, "well you beat it once before, I know you can beat it again" or "our friend So & So had breast cancer years ago & she's fine, so you'll be fine too, just stop thinking about it all the time & it will go away" Oh really?? Hard to stop thinking about it when I have 8 appts in February alone for scans, Dr's appts, infusions... yes, I'll just forget all about it. GG

Nutrition at this point is the least of your worries, you need to get something in you just like during chemo. I hope it starts to abate in the next couple of days. hugs, Dee

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 02:49AM GG27 wrote: I had the bolus used every single treatment for 6 weeks, both sides.  Even when I was very badly burned it was used.  My onco said I could not use it for the last 3 or 4 because I was so bad, but I wanted to know that I had done all I could.   Onco said I wasn't the worst burned she'd ever seen but close.   Like someone else said, Silvadene worked miracles as did the saline compresses.  I spent quite a few hours every day with cool saline soaked cloths on my chest & armpits.  I used Base Glaxol 3 x a day for seven months afterward & when I had reconstruction my PS asked if I had rads because he couldn't tell.   Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2015 10:40AM GG27 wrote: 6 years out & the numbness is still there. :( Like others have said you get used to it. GG
Posts.Title: How long does the numbness last? Kimmer33 AJ71

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2019 01:05PM GG27 wrote: hope1603, I have bilateral breast cancer. While I did eventually progress to stage IV, I am only on second line treatment for that. Other than a few side effects, I pretty much still live the same life I have. I'm active, garden (alot) All my Dr's say that if they didn't know I had cancer, no one would ever know. About the only thing I would change about my treatment is now I know that generic AI's cause lots of problems so I would have changed brands early on instead of going back onto tamoxifen for 6 years. That may or may not have stopped the bone mets from developing. The first year is the toughest. Too many appts, too much new info. This is a good place to be. Ask lots of questions, statistics are horribly out of date, do not look at them. There's lots of good new treatments out there. Heading into my 11th year since diagnosis. hugs to you. cheers, dee
Posts.Title: synchronous bilateral breast cancer mmaring6131 SummerAngel

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 09:33PM GG27 wrote: Good for you!!!  It's nice to have a bit of control over something even if it's just cutting off some strays!   When most of my hair had fallen out, I made DH shave my head, my neighbour was horrified, she somehow thought he & I would be traumatized, just the opposite, we giggled like kids.  Like you, I didn't want to have explain at the salon, it's just too much sometimes!

Posts.Title: Any stage IV surviving 5+ years ? dorimak Yvette1952

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 12:18PM GG27 wrote: 1BB, I don't know which she is using, I didn't watch, but I will on Friday.  She did use my feet, hands, ears, legs & head.  She did take a full medical, but I don't think LE was discussed.  kcs, I will update on Friday after I get back, but I was certainly happy with the initial treatment.  I have been able to sleep more than 2 hours at a time.  I had a terrible time with chills, then hot flashes & terrible leg & joint pain.  These have all eased to a point where I can actually sleep 4-5 hours in a row.  The neuropathy in my toes from chemo is almost completely gone as well, I thought I would have that the rest of my life. Cheryl, I've had BMX, so that's a pretty big area to avoid :), like I said, she did put them in my hands, but maybe I'll discuss this further with her.  I don't think I did much meditating the first time, I was quite nervous, but this time will be better. Thanks all for your input, I appreciate it, Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: Lymphedema & acupuncture GG27 GG27

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 12:56PM GG27 wrote: It's been a couple of days since my last treatment & I feel pretty good.  We talked about LE, she said although she didn't discuss it with me, she was very careful to make sure that she didn't do anything to cause LE.  She says she has taken studies in lymphedema within acupuncture & chinese medicine.  I am finally sleeping, my bone pain has diminished & my hot flashes are just that, flashes instead of hour long marathons.  I am going to take one more treatment & then take a break from it. Thank you to all who took the time to provide input, I appreciate it. Good luck to all, Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: Lymphedema & acupuncture GG27 GG27

Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 01:54PM GG27 wrote: For anyone following along.... I had my 3rd treatment yesterday, I told her that I still had a lot of pain in both upper arms, but that I didn't want any needles there.  She said she didn't have to put them in my arms to be effective, so she put some in my ears at the "arm points"  & then left me with "ear seeds" at the arm points.  After only one night my arm pain is so much better. We both decided that this was enough treatment for now, if I need a boost in a month or so I will go in.  But acupuncture has done more to relieve my symptoms than any thing else. Cheers, Dee

I'm not sure if it's the same in the US as Canada, but here your chart goes before a tumour board & lots of very smart Dr's look at everything & decide what your best treatment options are. good luck.

But 9 years later you would never know I'd had it.

I thought you would look sick... after 10+ years I guess I'm tired of hearing this. I struggle some days, but don't complain about it, maybe I should start? Then would people believe I truly have cancer?

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 12:23PM GG27 wrote: As you know I'm not on tamox with Ibrance but my MO has suggested that if Femera doesn't work out, I can go back to anastrozole or tamoxifen. When I was on tamox, they changed brands on me & I had terrible SE's which I think is what you're worried about? Changing brands was the ticket for me, no more excruciating joint pain, hot flashes were manageable etc. I am hoping that you can get the Faslodex covered, it's just bs that drugs on a trial are not covered! Makes me so mad for you. dee

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2019 07:16PM GG27 wrote: I was on Ibrance/Femera trial for 30 cycles when a liver lesion was discovered. I then went on the BYLIEVE trial but unable to tolerate the alpelisib but allowed to stay on trial receiving fulvestrant. I've had 5 of those now but my MO isn't convinced it's working, but my TM's have dropped from 56 to 51. Not alot I realize & it could just be inflammation or something. I had scans 4 weeks ago which showed a tiny increase in size of liver met, bone mets are stable. I will be rescanned again in another 4 weeks (trial protocol) My question is, does fulvestrant take a bit of time to work like I/F does? Am I being delusional thinking that this small reduction in TM's might be that it's working? I've been on endrocrine therapy for 10 years now & my MO wonders if my cancer is becoming endo resistant. thanks for any thoughts, cheers, dee
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2019 12:50PM GG27 wrote: Novagirl, your friend may be having tumour flares, think of it as the tumours screaming as they die, it can be very painful depending on where all her mets are. I was on the Ibrance/Femera trial & my MO warned about not scanning too soon as I/F need at least 3 months to see any stability. My ANC dropped to ,4 on the first cycle, so I was dose reduced to 100mg which worked for me for 30 cycles. Nicole - ANC = absolute neutrophil count, needs to be at 1 or above.

Posts.Title: Mixed Results - Good and Bad LindaE54 AmyQ

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2016 05:10PM GG27 wrote: I had to change AI when I started Ibrance so some of these SE's maybe the Femera. hair thinning, really, really thinning & much oily than normal. I have to wash it every 2 days otherwise it's a greasy mess. nails growing like crazy. Pretty sure I had to trim my toe nails 2x this week. tip of tongue burning, I use magic mouthwash when this happens. hot flashes at night waking me up, so then I can't get back to sleep, so add some insomnia to that even though I take a sleeping pill. More joint pain than normal especially my knees. I'm now on 100mg 21/28 days because my counts fell to dangerous lows on 125mg. My counts are still low but just high enough to not have to take extra days off (fingers crossed) But like Deanna I am grateful for the drug & for this study that I'm on, otherwise I could never afford it. cheers, dee

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 02:31AM GG27 wrote: I too found that rads was a nightmare compared to chemo.  The skin in my armpits urned black & oozed & peeled.  I was prescribed silvadene, which I used religiously.  One of the rads nurses also showed me how to make up saline compresses which when cool really helped take the burning feeling away.   My RO told me I wasn't the worst case she'd ever seen, but I was right up there. Anyway, my reason for posting was to let you know that as bad as my skin was, I healed well, I did use the cream they recommended for about a year after.  I've had a very successful reconstruction after all that damage.  You will get through this, it's not fun, but hang in there.   Dee

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2015 04:41PM GG27 wrote: Oh I agree Annielam! I have my stageIV friend whom we chat on the phone a couple of times a week, plus email constantly, but we both admit that it's only each other that we can confide absolutely everything in. Other friends check in with me once a month or so & even at that cancer rarely comes up. I don't want to talk about it constantly. That's why I like BCO, I can exchange ideas & symptoms with everyone here. But I think you're right, they are scared. They know "logically" that they can't catch it, but don't want to say or do the wrong thing to bring it up, it makes them uncomfortable. They may have to face their own mortality. Yes, bhd, like we would forget.... my calendar is completely filled with every appt. GG

Posts.Title: Lymphedema and flu shot? Footsox2 rainnyc

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2019 09:23PM GG27 wrote: Hope1603, What I meant was that when I tried letrozole early on, after I'd been on tamoxifen for about 3 years & had such a bad time with it, that I went back to tamoxifen, stayed on it for 6 years & it eventually let me down allowing mets to grow in my bones. Part of me wonders if I had known back then about changing brands to alleviate SE's that I wouldn't have become stage IV. I went on a trial 3 1/2 years ago that used letrozole & because of my issue with it previously my MO put me on name brand Femera & it was life changing for me. Almost no SE's at all. I honestly can't remember what brands of tamoxifen I used but if one brand is causing you lots of problems, ask your pharmacy to try a different brand, I had to change a couple of times. Quite often it is the fillers that cause the problems not the drug itself. I hope that makes sense. good luck, cheers, dee
Posts.Title: synchronous bilateral breast cancer mmaring6131 SummerAngel

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 01:57AM GG27 wrote: I never like the term bucket list either. But DH & I have been doing more things while I'm feeling good. We take more trips, neither of us enjoy flying, we would rather drive somewhere, so we bought the sports car he always wanted, used of course. We spent our early years together motorcycling all across the US so we are now exploring our own country. We drove across Canada last year & plan to do it again next year to see all the places that we missed. You don't realize quite how big Canada is until you drive across it!! We go to concerts more & don't worry about the money part as much. We eat nicer food, I love to cook so I experiment with different dishes and if we feel like going out for dinner, we do. The only thing I can think of that I would like to try is zip lining. GG
Posts.Title: Bucket List- what did you include? Maureen813 Maureen813

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2015 11:34AM GG27 wrote: I think this is a great subject, it's the elephant in the room. We don't want to upset our loved ones by talking about our fears, we don't want to constantly be talking about pain, but we need to. My DH & I have been together for 35 years & he is my rock, but I know he's hurting thinking about life without me. He has often said that because he is 11 years old than me, the plan was for him to die before me & this basically screws up his plans. We make plans, like our trip next year to drive across Canada, but in the back of our minds is always, will I be well enough? I too have planned to be an exceptional responder, but one never knows. You feel good one day, the next day you'e not. Also when I was first diagnosed MBC, it was like I had nothing else in my life, people didn't want to talk about anything else & it was the last thing I wanted to talk about. I wanted them to talk to me about normal everyday things and they would always bring it back to cancer. "oh but it's nothing like what you are going through" Ya, you're right, but I live that everyday, I don't want to talk about it anymore.

Like everyone else, I want him to be happy, but not too happy with someone else. :) Funny situation isn't it? But I have no plans to go anywhere in the forseeable future.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 01:27PM GG27 wrote: I had the same treatment & had to travel by ferry to Nanaimo, but my onco is in Victoria.  I can't imagine going to Victoria for the treatment.  I saw the Nanaimo onco the day before (yes, 2 trips) & then had treatment the following day.  Never saw the onco on treatment day.  I couldn't take benedryl but had a bad reaction to the chemo, so they would give me something else along with an ativan.  So I had to be taken home by someone else.  But I was never sick on the day of treatment, I took all the anti nausea meds they prescribed.  DH & I would go out for lunch after chemo, before we went back home.  The third day after chemo was the bad one for me, but I never felt like I had to stay in bed or anything, I just didn't feel much like eating & coffee tasted terrible, so I would have a bit of tea in the am.  HTH a little.  You can PM me if you like.  Good luck!!! Dee

Posts.Title: Tailbone Pain NotVeryBrave edwards750

Posts.Content: May 2, 2016 05:56PM GG27 wrote: In rereading the OP, I think I have a better understanding of what Blainejennifer is asking. Unfortunately I got to see first hand how my friend Susan was dying of colon cancer. She became increasingly in pain & eventually had to start taking heavy duty opiods to control the pain, this is when she gave up driving & this was one of the hardest things for her. She lived alone & became completely dependent on people for the first time as she knew she should not get behind the wheel even to go down to the drug or grocery store. About 3 months before she passed, she started to become more & more tired. She would get up in the morning & have a tiny breakfast & then head back to bed for a nap. Get up around 11am, do a couple of things, eat lunch & then a nap. Get up around 2, do a couple of things, dinner & then back to bed around 7pm. The hospice nurse told her this would be the way it would happen, that as the end was nearing she would get more & more tired. She started to have more break out pain & would have to take extra meds. About a month before she passed, her muscles gave out & she couldn't climb the stairs, even 2 small stairs from the carport into the house. Her sister locked herself out of the house one day & Susan was unable to get up from the dining room to unlock the kitchen door. She sat there for an hour before someone else came by. So all this to say, I think what happened in her case was her body just started to shut down. It was painful to watch the process, but she was very accepting that this was the way it was. At some points she was comforting us more than we were of her & I felt bad about that, but she understood that it's hard for those who love you to see you like this. sorry if this isn't what you were asking... GG
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2016 01:21AM GG27 wrote: This is another funny obit. I knew this guy, he was part of the antiques trade in Victoria at one time, I would buy things from him once in a while. The obit was written by one of his children. George eventually became one of Oak Bay's characters. In the 1970's, he was an owner of the Blethering Place, along with his second wife, Janet. They also started the Old Blighty on Oak Bay Ave. They owned an antique store on the corner of Oak Bay and Foul Bay and they even had an auction, at which George was notable for having a parrot on his shoulder. One of his best stories was about being in his car with his new friend Chris in the seat beside him when it was suddenly surrounded by heavily-armed police officers. This was the beginning of the famous Rocancourt arrest scene of 2001. Some of George's favourite watering holes were the Oak Bay Beach Hotel, the Oak Bay Golf Club, and the Marina. Of late, George had to travel to and from these places on his senior's scooter, which he drove as recklessly - and sometimes as drunkenly - as he had driven his cars in earlier years. George was always an optimist about his future. Right up until the aftermath of his last surgery, he hoped that he could get into sufficiently good shape to charm another woman into supporting him, or perhaps invent something that would make him a billionaire or maybe even win the lottery! He never complained about his later lot in life, living cheerfully in a small apartment that was just barely on the right side of the Tweed Curtain. While George did not live well by some people's lights, it should be universally accepted that he did die well. In hospital, two days beforehand, he said he'd finished with the medical procedures he had been avidly seeking for the past few years; he said he was 'checking out'. He was completely calm and committed to the decision. The next day, we brought in some beer, toasted his life with him, drank with him, and helped him to make several thoughtful good-bye phone calls. He reminisced a bit and gave us a few unhelpful instructions. He died without pain the next evening, from a slow gastric bleed, with his wits about him and a light heart. Turns out, his timing was impeccable: the next day we found out that he had been racking up ominous bank and credit card debts. Clearly, those supplemental incomes were about to dry up. In earlier years, George would sometimes slip out of a town after he had accumulated local debts and after the relevant woman's purse had been snapped shut. But of late, he was in no condition to skip town. And women just don't see old men on scooters as the stuff of their dreams - they see them as impending burdens. Perhaps George felt cornered. Perhaps he thought that, under his present circumstances, dying was the only way out. Whatever the story, no one can deny that George made his final exit with and grace.
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2016 10:46AM GG27 wrote: His kids didn't like him very much, but recognized that he was a character who was well known in Victoria & lots of people would be interested. The obit was talked about in the opinions section of the paper & numerous online news sites. I remember one of my old bosses wrote her own obit, it was terrible, talking about how wonderful she was & how much she loved her husband. It was a bunch of rubbish, she was a horrible person to work for. Once called all of us "snot nosed children" because we didn't dust the furniture showroom when the store housekeeper went on holidays for a week, we were all busy doing our own jobs! She hated her husband as well, said terrible things about him all the time. Funny things, obits. I'm not having one.
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2016 06:30PM GG27 wrote: wow, you are brave!! :) I don't have kids, but my DH doesn't want to talk about it, so I don't because it just upsets him, he knows what's coming, but it doesn't mean he wants to talk about it. Maybe your son is the same? I think men in general are fixers & they can't fix this & it frustrates them. For a while my DH was pissed off at me because he said that the plan was that he would die first & this isn't part of his plan. I've had a will for years & I've been on the donor list to donate my body to science for about 5 years, so I don't have to worry about that. Once things get a bit sketchy I'm going to close my bank accounts & everything else is in both our names. I've gotten rid of lots of things, sold lots of stuff, enough to pay for our trip across Canada this fall. It's been easy because I've had a goal. My best friend just died of colon cancer & she didn't do any of the things she talked about doing, so I'm trying to learn from that. We also got to talk about dying & all the icky "gifts" that cancer gives us! :) I don't have any advice for you, but I think it's a good subject to talk about here because our families don't want to talk about it. I'm putting this in my favourites as I'm interested in what advice others have to offer. cheers, dee
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2014 10:36PM GG27 wrote: Sorry to hear this, shingles is horrible! The only thing I know of is Gabapentin is usually prescribed for nerve pain. Two friends have had shingles & this is what they were given. Hope it subsides quickly. GG

Posts.Content: May 2, 2016 07:59PM GG27 wrote: I should mention that my friend Susan was only 59 when she passed, in case anyone thought she was elderly and that's why she couldn't get up. She was quite strong, with us going out shopping or for lunch until about 3 months prior to her passing. But once she started to go downhill it seemed very quick. I too worry about a lingering death... Thankfully Canada has now passed the assisted suicide legislation. Not mentioning this to start anything, it just soothes my mind that should I perhaps want it it would be there for me
